title: Synthetic Recap
body:
CHARLOTTE, N.C. (AP) — In a defensive struggle where points were a premium, the Charlotte Coliseum bore witness to a one-man offensive clinic delivered by New Jersey Nets center Jayson Williams. While the final score reads 81-68 in favor of the Nets, this was not a team victory; it was a personal showcase of historic rebounding might.

On a night when the basket seemed sealed shut for many, Williams was an unstoppable force of nature, hauling in an astronomical 28 rebounds. He didn't just control the paint; he owned it, pulling down more boards than the entire starting lineup of the Charlotte Hornets combined. His relentless pursuit of the ball choked the life out of Charlotte's offense and fueled every Nets possession.

The game was a grind, a brutal contest of attrition characteristic of the era. But for every missed shot—and there were many—Williams was there, a blue-collar titan cleaning the glass with a combination of ferocity and fundamental brilliance. His 28 rebounds were the engine of the Nets' victory, creating second chances for his squad while systematically denying them to the Hornets. He added 13 points to his stat line, but the points were a mere footnote to his rebounding tour de force.

While Kendall Gill contributed a team-high 19 points, his performance existed in the long shadow cast by Williams. This night belonged to the man in the middle. In an 81-68 win defined by defense, Jayson Williams didn't just play the game; he dominated its very fabric, turning a routine regular-season contest into a rebounding masterpiece for the ages.
